<description type="note">Preliminaries omitted ; verse reproduced elsewhere in American

A New Brand of Cigars âLa Marie Jansenâ is a new brand of cigars that has been devised, manufactured, and uttered by an enterprising Boston man named Horace S. Woodbury. The vivacious lady who gives her name to these delectable weeds has honored us with a box of them, and we desire to testify to the superior quality of the same (the cigars). The Jansen has no equal among domestic goods, nor have we seen any foreign article that we prefer to it. It is of medium size, of proper heft, is well filled, and it imparts a singularly pleasing flavor to one's mouth. We know not how better to express our approval of this paragon of home industry than in these eloquent words of the inspired poet: âThe weed that's imported is commonly courted, But I claim that the home-made will do, sir; So I hullaballoo f'r th' indigenous two-f'r, And stand for the red-white-and-blue, sir. The Jansen's the smoker for this jolly jokerâ It draws well, is fragrant and dapper; It is so much the best that I'd swap all the rest For just oneâin a cute little wrapper.â The Rime of the Crow Eater Into the market place there came (One autumn morning murky) An old and battered veteran To choose a proper turkey. His coat tails and his shrunken shanks Had cockle burrs stuck to 'em, And his whiskers looked as if the wind Of winter had blown through 'em. And still as through those whiskers white The breezes rudely fluttered, The old man from a cracker-box This strange recital uttered: âTwice two long years,â says he, âI've sot Around the Grand Pacific, And all that twice two years the feed Has simply been terrific.â THE GRAND PACIFIC âFor twice two years I've eaten crow In widely various weathers; Not only meat and skin and bones, But also claws and feathers!â A CROW âThe crow it is a dismal bird, And deeply I abhor it; For twice two years I've lived on crow, Though never clamoring for it. ââWhat have we on the bill to-day?â I'd question of the waiter; âTurk fer the rest,â sez he, âbut you Gets crow an' cold pertater!â âThey gave me crow in every style And every foreign name, sirâ Alas! no matter how disguised, Crow always is the same, sir! âThough it be christened Ã la mode, Still is its flavor queer, sir; No rhetoric can mitigate Its consequences here, sir! âIn vain I fled from John B. Drake To other restauraters; In vain I sought for victuals else Than crow and cold pertaters!â A RESTAURANT âThey fed me crow and only crow Until I thought I'd die, sir; I got so full of crow at last I half opined I'd fly, sir! âFor, as I said a spell ago, In fair and stormy weathers, I ate not only the skin and bonesâ I ate also the feathers! âThe crow it is a noxious bird To stomachs such as mine is; But, heaven be praised! there is no ill But some time has its finis! âOnce, as I chewed the bitter cud Of gloomy introspections, A cheery voice broke in upon The thread of my reflections. âI looked up and saw the face Of Captain John R. Tanner! I heard salvation in his voiceâ I saw it in his manner! âAt once dispelled were gnawing griefs And apprehensions gloomy; Of all the spectacles on earth, This was the most precious to me!â SPECTACLES ââJohn! John!â I wailed, âgive piteous ear Unto my tale of woe, sir; For twice two years I've eaten crow, And eaten only crow, sir! ââWhat wonder is it that I cry, âO tempora! O mores!â Since gnawing crow has worn away My dentes incisores!ââ DENTES INCISORES ââThe bird of which you speak,â says John, âIt, too, has been my living; But, Bailey, you and I shall gorge On turkey, come Thanksgiving! ââSee here; I have a subtle soup Corked up in this decanter, With which I'll prove âsimilia Similibus curantur!â ââI shall inject this subtle soup Into our common foe, sir; Then shall we get the turkey-bird, And they shall get the crow, sir! ââBut never mind particularsâ Just wait and watch the sequel! Oh, we shall lead them such a dance As never had an equal!ââ A DANCE ââTwas even as John Tanner said, And you will not deny it If you observe, Thanksgiving Day, My changed and sumptuous diet! âTimes are more prosperous than they wereâ Once more we've peace and plenty; Turkey shall be my dainty feast Next week, Deo volente! âFor twice two years I've lived on crow Through ever changeful weathersâ Those twice two cycles fed on skins, Bones, inwards, claws and feathers.â TWICE TWO CYCLES âBut fickle fate has brought me joy, And, feeling blithe and perky, I've come into the market place To fetch a bouncing turkey. âNo senile, starveling bird will doâ But one that's young and tender; One that is whiskerless and plump, And of the female gender!â A TURKEY âI'll carve it next Thanksgiving Day, And pour the oyster sauce onâ 'Twill be a goodly change from crow!â Quoth grand old Bailey Dawson [A New York critic, Winter hight] A New York critic, Winter hight, Upon a time did sore despite A play & him as he wrote it; He set a straw man on a hill; Then, couching his prodigious quill, Most grievously he smote it. âMeseemeth, 'neath that poet guise The baseborn caitiff Lathrop liesâ And he's the prey I've layed for; & it behooves me now to fare Against that prey and raise its hairâ Syn that is what I'm paid for.â So up & down that critic rased & backe & foorth he foyned & trased & monstrous strookes deliverd; Till that, from hacking at that straw In direst wise you ever saw, His quill was all to-shivered. & when he made an end at last & when that man of straw was brast Like so much straw asunder, Loud laughen peoples all to see That critic angred for that he Had made a grewsome blunder. It was not Lathrop that he slew, Though that was what he meant to do With his egregious feather; 'Twas Tennyson he slew so boldâ Then was that critic, we ben told, Beset by wintry weather. Inter-State Commerce In 'eighty-six right evil tricks Reformers sought to play; They formed a pool wherewith to fool The state that had to pay. With divers winks and smiles, methinks, One Rees the pillage plannedâ And as for Clen (that best of men)! He took a quiet hand. He argued so (by which you'll know A godly man was he): âQuite different things are pools from ringsâ This pool's the thing for me! âFor years I've been a foe to sinâ I find it does not pay; I'll share your guile a little while, But am not in to stay! âWhen breezes blow and blasts of woe Seem threatening every minute, I'll skip the game to save my name And swear I wasn't in it!â 'Twas thus to each his cautious speech In godly phrases ran; âWhate'er betide,â the others cried, We'll âsave the honest man!â The crash has come and there are some Who thinks that Clen's to blame, But Rees et al, defend their pal, And bless his righteous name. And Clen denies and rolls his eyes In fashion most dejected; It's hard on Clen when godly men Are not from wrath protected. Rev. Sam Small and Rev. Sam Jones I. âI'll never chaw terbackerâno, Nor smoke, nor snuff at all! Folks say it is a deadly sin,â Says Rev. Samuel Small. II. But lo! as if in answer to His partner's chiding tones: âI shaw terbacker, and I smoke! Says Rev. Samuel Jones. III. But seeing how the Rev. Small And other folks did scoff. Because he used the filthy weed, The Rev. Jones swore off. IV. So glory be to Small and Jones, Those best of preacher-men, And let us pray that, since they're off, They'll not swear on again.
